column4: Good Evening. I've run into a problem and it's made me a little nervous. After mounting an NTFS partition in Ubuntu and copying some data, I booted into Win 7. It wanted to run checkdisk and after that, the partition was no longer readable by Windows or Ubuntu. I'm currently doing data recovery, but I'm not sure what caused the issue.
Some googling revealed people with similar problems with a drive that moved from Ubuntu to Win7 and back again, but no solutions or insights into what caused it.
I've never had this issue with my WinXP/Ubuntu 10.10 dual-boot setup, just the Win7/Ubuntu 11.04 setup.
what does ubuntu say when it refuses to mount it?
if I do it from Nautilus, I get that it exited with a code 2... from the prompt, no errors, it just doesn't mount.
how are you mounting that partition on terminal?
then you should let windows check the disk
my plan is to let it do the checkdisk after the data is safe on a removable drive. I've had checkdisk make a bad problem worse in the past.
if you are just accessing your files on Linux for reading, mount your ntfs read-only then
I'm still trying to get to the bottom of why it occurred in the first place. I don't know if it was ntfs-3g or Win7 that caused the issue, so I'm hesitant to plug anything into my machine now. :(
without any info, we cannot tell
indeed. Just wondered if anyone has seen anything similar happen.
but if you mounted it on linux and then a shutdown was forced without umounting it
that might cause the partition to be marked unclean and prompt for checks to be done on it

I've been in and out of the Live CD for a few days.. it's possible. Still doesn't explain why Windows ran the checkdisk and then I couldn't access the data. But, If I figure it out, I'll definitely come back and share anything interesting.
was the whole drive inaccessible or your data? were you able to create new files or folders into it or not?
the first ntfs partition is fine, the second ntfs partition couldn't be mounted or accessed by Windows... Windows even still assigned it a drive letter...
I can't do much with it at the moment anyway, it's restoring 331GB to an external drive via USB 2.0.. :-S I didn't have an eSATA cable handy.
